In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the code snippet in Julia:
```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime; bump=3)
    dt + Hour(bump)
end

function timezone_bumper(d::Date)
    throw(ArgumentError("Can't increase the timestamp for Date type, use DateTime instead."))
end
```
This code first checks if `dt` is of `DateTime` type. If it is not, function will return error. Then it increases the `dt` by `bump` hours using `Hour(bump)`. This bumped timestamp is then returned.
